Sheltered in Ratlam District of Madhya Pradesh, Sailana is smaller than other wildlife sanctuaries in Madhya Pradesh, but no less beautiful! Housing a plethora of flora and fauna, the place is most celebrated for its luscious cactus garden that.Â
Comprising the Sanjay-Dubri Tiger Reserve, the sanctuary is located in the dry deciduous forests of the Narmada Valley. It is the abode of several exquisite avian species and wildlife.Â

Amer Fort is a fort cum palace that greets youÂ with warm Rajasthani folk musicÂ andÂ mesmerizes you with its beauty. Precision of carvings and embedment of stones prove that it is aÂ finely-crafted marvel.Â BeingÂ perched on a hillock of Aravali Range, Amer Fort has been regarded as a UNESCO World Heritage Site along with other hill forts of Rajasthan.

Overlooking the Blue City of Jodhpur from a height from 125 meters,Â Mehrangarh FortÂ was commissioned back in 1460 by Rao Jodha.Â This rigid yet fascinating structure has beenÂ featured in many movies, like The Dark Knight Rises and Awarapan. The fort has many palaces that flaunt immaculate carving and the signature interiors of the regal Rajasthan in the past.

One of the largest forts in India,Â Jaisalmer FortÂ wasÂ built in 1156 AD by King Rawal Jaisal. Merging with the golden desertscape of Jaisalmer, itÂ isÂ often regarded asÂ Sonar QuilaÂ or the Golden Fort.Â The fort is nestled on a hill, 76 meters above the city and is located in the heart of Jodhpur.Four grand entrances, Royal Palace, Lakshminath Temple, Jaisalmer Fort Palace Museum and Heritage Centre and palaces of the merchants

One of the most popular forts inÂ Rajasthan, Ranthambore Fort is located in the largest national park of Rajasthan, Ranthambore National Park. Snuggled in the warmth of wilderness, Ranthambore Fort was built in the middle of tenth century. However, the exact date of its construction is yet disputed.Like the other hill forts of Rajasthan, the entrance of Ranthambore Fort is led through stairwell and looks upon a vast expanse of the verdant vicinity.

Built on 180 meters-high hill, Chittorgarh Fort is spread over an expansive area of 700 acres with seven massive gateways called Pol. ItÂ is also often known asÂ Water Fort, as there are aboutÂ 22 water bodies inside the fort.Interestingly, the Chittorgarh Fort has been destroyed thrice and has witnessed the reign of three rulers â€“ Allauddin Khilji, Bahadur Shah and Maharana Udai Singh.

Counted among the best forts in Rajasthan, Taragarh Fort served as a center for military activities during the Mughal rule in Ajmer. Also, it was known for its tunnels that went through the entire hill it stands on.Built in 1354 AD, the fort offersÂ an impressive panoramic view of the area. Its three main gateways â€“ Gagudi Ki Phatak, Lakshmi Pol and Phuta Darwaza â€“ are key tourist attractions here.

Birthplaces of the great Mewar Ruler, Â Maharana Pratap,Â Kumbhalgarh FortÂ is one of the most popular and best forts in Rajasthan. ItÂ was built by Maharana Kumbha in 15th century, after whom the fort is named.Interestingly, Kumbhalgarh is also revered for having second-longest wall in the world, covering an area of 36 km sq. The route to the fort too is an interesting one, as ravines and thick woods greet you. If you are planning a visit here, pick a nice stay from the best hotels in Kumbhalgarh and explore the fort at leisure.

Among the most immaculately crafted Rajasthan heritage forts, Junagarh deserves a special mention. This fort in Bikaner, isÂ one of the few forts of Rajasthan which arenâ€™t built on a ridge. Junagarh Fort, being the beauty it is and was, stole hearts of many rulers, which led to many attacks to conquer it. However, nobody wonÂ except Kamran Mirza (Son of Babar) who did it for merely a day.

In 1750, Jal Mahal was built by Maharaja Jai Singh for picnics with his family.Â Silently sitting in the middle of Mansagar Lake, itÂ is pretty much like a star everyone loves to glance at. The palace has five stories with chhatris and cenotaphs, exhibiting rich Rajput and Mughal style of architecture.After restoration work in 2005, this little historical marvel got a new face altogether. Today not just the fort looks magnificent but a lot many migratory birds find home here.

Hawa MahalÂ is among the most clicked Rajasthan forts and palaces. Its iconic honeycomb-structured windows totally steal the show. ItÂ was built in the year 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh.Â The windows, or jharokhas, in its facade were built for the queens and princesses so that they could enjoy looking at the hustle and bustle around the palace, without being seen.

Elevating the charm of Venice of the East, Lake Palace is among the best heritage hotels without doubt. Honeymoon couples shouldnâ€™t miss on this. The Lake Palace dates back to 1743 and now itâ€™s aÂ luxury property with 83 roomsÂ that will make you revisit the olden era with the comfort of modern facilities.Houses the second largest freshwater man made lake in Asia, vintage and classic car collection.

Initially a huge palace boasting of the historicaal heritage, this palace was converted into a hotel where you can now feel like a maharaja with world-class amenities. The hotel is managed by Taj Group of Hotels andÂ boasts of 347 opulent rooms.Â Umaid Bhawan PalaceÂ has also well-deservingly won the Worldâ€™s Best Hotel by TripAdvisor recently and it certainly is a place you cannot miss.

Paragliding in RajasthanÂ is not popular and the reason is the open and sandy region that the state has.But, with time the demand for this sport has increased and you will find paragliding events taking place in various cities like Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Pushkar, and Jaipur to attract visitors and tourists.The top view of Mount Abu, the desert area, and the royal cities of Rajasthan is indescribable which makes paragliding one of the bestÂ adventure sports in Rajasthan.

It is quite interesting to walk over one of the oldest mountain ranges in the world. Aravalli hills are a bit rocky, but they will only add thrill to your trekking.Trekking in Rajasthan can also be done at various places like Udaipur, Kumbhalgarh, Ranakpur, etc.The famous trekking belts are Sariska-Alwar-Amer and Udaipur-Kumbhalgarh-Chittorgarh belts.
Arrangements made by the management cannot be questioned as they all are trained professionals.You can try out bungee jumping in Rajasthan in Jaipur, Bikaner, Kota, and other places.

A hot air balloon ride over the scenic palaces, pristine lakes, dry deserts is what gives you an out-of-the-world experience.The rides totally depend upon the weather conditions. Ranthambore National Park in Sawai Madhopur is one of India's most prominent tiger reserves, renowned for its significant tiger population. Set against the backdrop of the Ranthambore Fort, the park offers a picturesque canvas of lakes, meadows, and ravines. Apart from tigers, the national park is home to a wide variety of wildlife, including leopards, hyenas, and marsh crocodiles.

column2: Mukundra Hills National Park, Tiger Reserve
column4: Mukundra Hills National Park in Rajasthan is one of the newest tiger reserves in India, offering breathtaking landscapes with dense forests, deep valleys, and the serene waters of the Chambal River. Home to a diverse range of flora and fauna, it is particularly known for the protection and conservation of the endangered tiger population. The park also plays a significant role in bridging the forested areas of Ranthambore and Chambal.

Keoladeo National Park, formerly known as Bharatpur Bird Sanctuary, is a world-renowned avian paradise and a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Bharatpur, Rajasthan. The park boasts over 370 species of birds, making it a prime destination for birdwatchers and ornithologists. Its wetlands, woodlands, and grasslands provide a unique habitat mix, attracting migratory birds, especially during the winter months.

Desert National Park in Jaisalmer offers a unique and exquisite desert ecosystem, making it one of the largest national parks in India. The park boasts a rich variety of wildlife, including the endangered Great Indian Bustard, and an array of fossils believed to be around 180 million years old. Sand dunes occupy about 20% of the park area, offering an authentic feel of the Thar Desert.

column2: Sariska National Park & Wildlife Sanctuary , Alwar
column4: Sariska National Park & Wildlife Sanctuary in Alwar offers a lush green landscape dotted with ruins and historical monuments, presenting a blend of nature and history. Once the royal hunting grounds of the Alwar state, the sanctuary is now a prime tiger territory, with its dense forests home to various wildlife species. It is well known for successfully relocating and reintroducing the majestic Bengal tiger.

Mount Abu Wildlife Sanctuary is nestled in the Aravalli Range, offering a refreshing contrast to the arid landscapes of Rajasthan. Covering a significant stretch of the hill station, it's home to diverse flora and fauna, including rare orchids, sambhars, and leopards. The sanctuary's cool climate and verdant surroundings make it an oasis for nature lovers and trekkers.

Darrah Wildlife Sanctuary in Kota was once the royal hunting ground of the Maharajas of Kota. This sprawling sanctuary, located along the southeastern border of Rajasthan, is a haven for various animal species including wolves, nilgai, cheetahs, and deer. Its dry deciduous forests and rivers create a unique ecosystem that draws both wildlife enthusiasts and tourists.

Machia Biological Park in Jodhpur is a popular destination offering a glimpse into the diverse flora and fauna of Rajasthan. Positioned near the Kaylana Lake, the park is home to a variety of animals, including the majestic lion. Additionally, it offers an incredible viewpoint named "Machia Fort" that provides panoramic views of the Blue City, Jodhpur.

Bassi Wildlife Sanctuary is located near the historic city of Chittorgarh in Rajasthan and offers a diverse range of flora and fauna. Spread over an area of 288 sq. km, it is home to animals like panthers, wild boars, and mongoose, as well as various avian species, making it an appealing destination for wildlife enthusiasts.

Sajjangarh Wildlife Sanctuary surrounds the famous Sajjangarh Palace in Udaipur and is located on the Bansdara hill. It offers a panoramic view of the surrounding landscapes and lakes and is home to a variety of wildlife including sambhar, wild boars, and hyenas. The sanctuary provides a serene backdrop to the Monsoon Palace, enhancing the grandeur of the hilltop royal residence.

Birla Mandir in Jaipur is one of the most famous temples in Rajasthan located on the foothills of Moti Dungari hills in the capital state, Jaipur. This temple was built by the Birla family in the 20th century. It is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and Goddess Lakshmi, though there are statues of other deities as well. Three large domes of this temple are at the centre of attraction here. As marble has been used to build this temple, it aesthetically appeals to all visitors.

Karni Mata Temple is located at Deshnoke in Bikaner which is around 30 km from Bikaner city. This temple is dedicated to Karni Mata that is believed to be an incarnation of Maa Durga. Its Mughal architecture appeals to tourists as well as devotees. An interesting fact about this temple is that it is popularly known as â€˜temple of ratsâ€™ as approximately 20000-25000 black rats reside in the temple premises. The main ritual of this temple is to feed the rats.

column2: Shree Rani Sati Dadi Mandir, Jhunjhunu
column4: Shree Rani Sati Dadi Mandir or simply Rani Sati Temple is located in Jhunjhunu district of Rajasthan. Dedicated to Rani Sati who had committed Sati on her husbandâ€™s pyre, Rani Sati is also called as Narayani Devi and referred to as Dadiji in local connotation. It is considered as one of the most famous temples in Rajasthan for exclusive theme and deity. The temple is built from white marble and decorated with various colourful wall paintings. It is surrounded by gardens and so are many other temples located inside this temple complex.

Ambika Mata Temple is located in Jagat Village near Udaipur city of Rajasthan at a distance of 50 km southwest. It is dedicated to Ambika Devi Deity who is a form of Goddess Durga. It seeks the attention of devotees as much as travellers appreciating art & sculpture here. Entire temple is decorated with various attractive sculptural works. Sculptures portray gods or goddesses besides musicians, dancers and singers projecting a virtual heavenly court.

column2: Galtaji Temples, Khania Balaji near Jaipur
column4: Ancient Hindu pilgrimage centre, Galtaji is located at a distance of approximately 10 km from Jaipur. A popular site among the devotees and tourists alike, its premises has a series of temples. Its strategic location of closeness to a place with natural spring emerging high on hills and flowing downwards beside the presence of many sacred kinds or water tanks for pilgrims to take holy bathe appeal to all and sundry.

Shila Mata Mandir or Shila Devi Temple in Amber Fort premises is a temple exclusively dedicated to Goddess Durga. This temple had been built under the guidance of Raja Man Singh I of Amer. It is one of the most popular temples in Rajasthan that witnesses the most exciting annual event of the celebration of nine days of Navratri. On the sixth day, special prayers are offered to Goddess Durga for her blessings. Besides usual visitors willing to explore the architectural richness of the temple and fort, hundreds of thousands of devotees keep flocking here during Navratri to seek blessings.

Govind Dev Ji Temple was built in 1735 CE under the guidance and instruction of Raja Sawai Jai Singh II. This temple is dedicated to one of the incarnations of Lord Krishna. Although, it is decorated throughout the year for devotees and touristsâ€™ arrival, it looks awesome during many Hindu festivals like Janmashtami, Navratri, Ram Navami, Kartik Purnima and Diwali etc.

Visitors with spiritual bent canâ€™t miss Salasar Balaji Temple in Rajasthan as it is one of the most important temples in the state. Popular amongst the devotees of Hanuman, this temple is dedicated to Lord Hanuman and is worshipped in sheer grandeur throughout the year. Tourists visiting Salasar make it a point to arrive here and explore this grand temple besides involving in special worships especially Ashvin Purnima and Chaitra Purnima pujas.

Jagatpita Brahma Temple, popularly known as Brahma Temple is located in the Pushkar city close to Pushkar Lake. It is one of the select few temples in the state dedicated to Lord Brahma, the creator of the world. The belief is that he had been cursed to not have any forms of worship on Earth. Therefore, if finding one temple dedicated to him holds a great amount of importance for his devotees. One of the ancient Rajasthan temples, it is said to be around 2,000 years old.

Shri Eklingji Temple has a unique identity as a Hindu temple in Udaipur, Rajasthan as besides this huge temple, several other temples are there within its high walls. Considered one of the most famous temples in Rajasthan to visit and worship Lord Shiva, this temple equally appeals to all travellers with its unique architectural beauty. This famous shire is an architectural marvel in the region thus a major tourist attraction in Udaipur besides serving the purpose of a holy place.

Johari is another name for jewellery, hence Johari Bazar is all about pretty Rajasthani jewellery. This market is known for intricate Kundan work and the traditional Meenakshi jewellery. All the exotic ornaments are beautifully adorned with precious and semi-precious gemstones. The vast collection of jewellery comes in different price ranges. So, this shopping arcade is never going to disappoint anyone. You can also get your hand on Rajasthani lehengas and saris in a few of the shops at Johari Bazaar.

The key attraction of Nehru Bazar is the pretty, multi-coloured jootis which enhances the look of ethnic outfits. Apart from footwear, textiles, bags, handicrafts and pottery are available in this market. It is a lively place and a popular hang-out for tourists and locals alike. Here, you need to use your bargaining skills to get your favourite items at the best price. Do not forget to shop for memorabilia and souvenirs from Nehru Bazar during your trip to Jaipur.

If you are a shopping aficionado, a trip to Jodhpur is incomplete without getting a glimpse of Nai Sarak. The speciality of this market are the bandhej and badhni apparels commonly known as tie and dye products which are a must buy for every tourist. You can also take home the beautiful turbans, leather items and hand-painted, vibrant saris which reflect the extravagant Rajasthani culture. Local artisans themselves make these products and sell them at Nai Sarak which means there are no middlemen involved.

One of the most significant markets in Jodhpur is the Sojati Gate Market. Choose from a myriad of Rajasthani handicrafts, accessories, jewellery, souvenirs as well as dye products. So, shop till you drop and satisfy the shopaholic within you. If you are a lover of henna designs, you would simply fall in love with this market. Decorate your palms with henna that look absolutely stunning and give the authentic Rajasthan vibe.

Bada Bazar is a one-stop destination for gold jewellery, clothing materials, silver and copperware. You name it and they have it. Some of the shops also sell precious gemstones, antique items, and leather goods. There are modern showrooms as well as street shops and the prices are also reasonable. Do not worry about the Rajasthan heat, there are a number of roadside stalls selling buttermilk, fruit juices and snacks that will refresh you instantly. Go munching and keep shopping.

Udaipur is all about stunning art and paintings and Hathi Pol Bazar is the finest example. Here you will find folk art and handicraft which are unique and fairly priced. It is one of the buzzing markets in Udaipur that swarms with tourists from different corners of the world. You can also take home with you beautiful Rajasthani footwear namely jootis and mojris. Locals quite often go shopping in this market, so there is a lesser chance for shopkeepers to overcharge.Â

Packed with traditional Rajasthani items, Sadar Bazar is one of the liveliest markets in Jaisalmer. Also, it is a perfect example of a typical Rajasthani ethnicity. When you are here, get your hands on blankets, rugs, carpets, apparels, handicrafts, antiques and so on. Apart from the Rajasthani charm, Sadar Bazar also offers other trendy items such as dye and Khadi fabric to name a few. And the best part, everything is available at a wholesale rate. So, even a stroll around this market will leave you dazzled.Â

Pansari Bazar, the oldest market in Jaisalmer is a shopper's paradise. Being the oldest market, it has retained its cultural and historic charm. Popularly known as villager's market, Pansari Bazar sells a wide variety of exquisite traditional pieces with a unique print, patterns and colours. It is a hub for Jaisalmer goodies namely ethnic wear, wall hangings, handicrafts, bells and puppets. Do not forget to take a bit of Rajasthan with you during your visit to the Pansari Bazar.

Kote Gate Road is a treasure trove for budget shoppers. Admire the architecture of Kote Gate and engage in shopping from the busy shops around you. This market is full of energy and exhibits the exuberant Rajasthani culture. Take home charming accessories made from camel hide, multi-coloured sandals, vibrant miniature paintings, colourful Khadi kurtas and the list goes on. A hot cup of tea made from camel's milk is a speciality of this market that will leave you rejuvenated and help you with your sightseeing expeditions.

Located at a distance of 258 km from Mumbai rests the very famous Shirdi Sai Baba Temple. The temple is known for being the abode of Sai. Every year, the town of Shirdi witnesses a massive footfall of followers and devotees who come seeking blessings of Sai Baba. Sai Baba is known to have been one of the greatest saints. The town of Shirdi is where Sai Baba attained Samadhi and hence, is a popular temple in Maharashtra. Over the years, the temple town has also been transformed into a very modern place with many tourist attractions.

Located on the coast of Konkan in Maharashtra lies the beautiful holy town of Ganpatipule. The small pilgrimage town is about 345 km from Mumbai and is close to the town of Ratnagiri. One of the main reasons it is named Ganpatipule is because it is famous for its 400-year-old Ganpati Temple. The alluring temple is located right on the beach and is believed for the self-incarnated idol of Ganesha. Ganpatipule is definitely one of the popular temples to visit in Maharashtra. Not only can you make a good weekend trip to visit the temple but also stay there with your family to soak in the serene atmosphere.

Situated at a distance of about 72 km from the holy town of Shirdi lies the famous Shani Shingnapur. It is one of the most popular temples in Maharashtra and should be visited. The temple is dedicated to Shani Mahadev, the Hindu god associated with the planet Saturn. It is a very famous pilgrimage place to visit in Maharashtra. It is a jagrut devasthan which means that the deity continues to reside in the temple. The popular temple in Maharashtra sees a massive throng of pilgrims who wish to seek blessings of Lord Shani and Lord Shiva.

Stationed in the lovely locales of Trimbak in Maharashtra is the popular Trimbakeshwar Jyotirlinga temple. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and has been attracting a plethora of pilgrims for a long time now. It is extremely popular for its Kushavarta Kund in Trimbak, which is a sacred bathing venue. The kund receives its water from the Godavari River. The temple was constructed by Peshwa Balaji Baji Rao and has three lingams of Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva in the premise. It is known to be one of the most famous and best temples in Maharashtra

Not only is Bhimashankar one of the most famous treks in Maharashtra, but it is also a popular temple in the state. Burrowed in the luscious green Sahyadri hills is the popular temple in Maharashtra. Bhimashankar Temple is undoubtedly one of the famous temples to visit in Maharashtra that should be on your list of religious places. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple is considered to be one of the 12 Jyotirlinga shrines in the country. Out of the 12 Jyotirlingas in the country, five of them are located in Maharashtra alone.

Nestled in the heart of Aundh is the popular Yamai Devi Temple in Maharashtra. The temple in Maharashtra is dedicated to Yamai Devi or better recognised as Devi Mahishasur Mardini. Yamai Devi's idol stands tall in the temple premise, adorned with trishul, arrow, gada and paan patra. The famous temple in Maharashtra is perched atop a hill which overlooks the beautiful valley in Aundh. Along with the temple, there are also quite a few sightseeing places to visit for a fabulous experience. You can take your family along with you for a religious expedition to visit Yamai Devi temple in Maharashtra and seek blessings of the goddess.

One of the most popular temples in Maharashtra is the Siddhivinayak Temple. The temple is dedicated to Lord Ganesha and is also touted to be one of the richest temples in India. The temple continues to see a footfall of millions every year as it is a very popular place to visit in Maharashtra. The Siddhivinayak Mandir has seen a handful of celebrities from the Bollywood industry as well as from many global leaders too, including Apple's CEO Tim Cook. The temple in Maharashtra is a temple that you should visit. Many devotees walk from home to the temple on Tuesdays as it is considered auspicious.

Nestled on the banks of the Panchganga River is the religious city of Kolhapur. The city of Kolhapur is known to be one of the essential spiritual centres with a significant collection of temples in Maharashtra. From Mahalakshmi Temple to Jyotiba Temple, there are many quaint temples in Kolhapur. A weekend getaway trip to Kolhapur would be a great way to spend time with family while visiting temples. Apart from visiting the temples in Kolhapur, you can also check out some of the tourist attractions in the city. Kolhapur sure has a slew of temples in Maharashtra that you can visit.

The temple of Harihareshwar in the Raigad district of Maharashtra is very famous for pilgrims who wish to visit the temple over the weekend. Nestled right on the Konkan coast, the town has been named after Harihareshwar which is dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is believed that Lord Shiva blesses the town of Harihareshwar. The temple is also surrounded by four hills namely, Harihareshwar, Bramhadri, Harshinachal and Pushpadri. It is one of the best temples to visit in Maharashtra as the ambience is certainly very serene. The holy beach town has been attracting many pilgrims over the years.

Part of the top 10 temples to visit in Maharashtra is the Grishneshwar Jyotirlinga Temple, located in the Aurangabad district. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple houses one of the jyotirlingas that have been mentioned in Shiva Purana. It is believed to be the 12th jyotirlinga, Lord Shiva is also acknowledged by various names including Ghrushmeswara, Kusumeswarar, Grishneswara and Ghushmeswara. The temple in Maharashtra has been constructed with red volcanic rock and was built during the reign of Rani Ahilyabhai Holkar and Maloji Raje Bhosale. The place lights up with festivities during Maha Shivratri.

Nagzira Wildlife Sanctuary is a very beautiful and quite a decent wildlife sanctuary which is located between Bhandara and Gondia district of Maharashtra. It is home to several wild animals, reptiles and birds of various species. It attracts a wide number of visitors owing to its picturesque landscapes and a great ambience. It was indeed a perfect place to visit with friends and family without an inch of doubt or hesitation.

Melghat Wildlife Sanctuary is a very popular reserve well located in Amravati district right on the Satpura Hill Range. The core area and the buffer area of the reserve are formed by the beautiful blend of Gugamal National Park and Chikhaldara Wildlife Sanctuary and it is decently recognised for the magnificent Tiger Reserve where other wildlife species such as Ussuri Dhole, Indian Leopard and Sloth Bear can be seen living on their natural habitat.

A pristine paradise of nature with lush hills, sparkling waterfalls, and dense forests, Bhimashankar Wildlife Sanctuary is the home of the Giant Flying Squirrel and is a favourite weekend getaway for people from Mumbai and Pune. Located a mere 138 km from Pune, Bhimashankar reserve is an all-in-one package of fun, adventure, nature, and spirituality. Challenging treks for adventure seekers, temples for pilgrims, diverse flora and fauna for nature lovers and wildlife photographers, various unique birds for bird watchers, picnic spots for families with kids, and beautiful natural locations for couples â€“ Bhimashankar Wildlife Reserve has something for every type of traveler!

Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary is a well-known wildlife sanctuary well situated in Satara District right amidst the mighty Western Ghats. It is widely visited by tourists as well as locals and you can truly spot a wide variety of wildlife species in its vicinity. Your visit here will be worth your time and money and it is highly recommended to visit here with your friend and family to enjoy such an amazing ambience and a delightful environment.

Sagareshwar Wildlife Sanctuary is a very renowned and recognised tourist destination located in Sangli District of Maharashtra. It is a great place to visit with your near and dear ones to witness a wide variety of wildlife animals such as deer, wild boar, striped hyena and porcupines living in their natural habitat. This sanctuary truly has got a lot of potential to offer to all of its visitors for sure which shall leave you amazed and with awe owing to its certain charm and mesmerising beauty in diversity.

Bor Wildlife Sanctuary is one of the finest wildlife sanctuaries located near Hingani right in the heart of Wardha District. It is indeed a very well recommended place to visit with friends and family owing to its wide variety of wildlife species and several species of birds which are seen and spotted living joyfully in their natural habitat. After being recognised as a tiger reserve it was eventually merged with the famous Pench tiger reserve in a pursuit to boost the exotic wildlife tourism in Maharashtra.
Accredited as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO, the Radhanagari Bison Sanctuary is the home to Indian Bison. Â The Sanctuary which is spread over 351 sq. km is home to a wide range of flora and fauna.

As one of the prominent museums in Maharashtra, the Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya stands as a true crown jewel of cultural heritage and largest museum in Mumbai. Formerly known as the Prince of Wales Museum, it houses an extensive assortment of art and artifacts from diverse corners of the globe. Among its prized possessions are relics from the ancient Indus Valley Civilization, providing a captivating glimpse into the region's early history. Boasting a remarkable collection of over 40,000 books and scriptures, the museum serves as a rich resource for knowledge-seekers. Beyond its fascinating exhibits, the museum's awe-inspiring architecture, representing British Saracenic style, adds an extra layer of allure to the whole experience.

Nestled among the distinguished museums in Maharashtra, the Coin Museum stands as a captivating repository of numismatic wonders. Showcasing a diverse array of coins, ranging from punch-marked and Indo-Greek to Kushan, medieval, and modern coins, the museum provides a fascinating journey through the evolution of currency. Among its prized possessions, visitors can marvel at rare finds like the gold Mohur of Emperor Jahangir and the silver Rupee of Emperor Akbar, offering a tangible connection to the past. With its extensive and precious collection, the Coin Museum offers an enriching experience for history enthusiasts and curious minds alike, shedding light on the importance of numismatics in understanding our shared heritage.

The Mahatma Gandhi Museum, located in Maharashtra, stands as a poignant tribute to the life and legacy of the Father of the Nation, Mahatma Gandhi. This historical museum in Maharashtra houses a remarkable collection of photographs, letters, documents, and artifacts that intimately depict Gandhi's extraordinary journey in leadingÂ India's struggle for independence. The museum finds its home in the iconic Mani Bhavan building, which witnessed several pivotal events in Gandhi's life, adding profound significance to the exhibits. A pilgrimage for those passionate about Indian history, the Mahatma Gandhi Museum offers a profound and immersive experience, allowing visitors to connect deeply with the ideals and sacrifices of this revered leader.

The National Maritime Museum, a captivating addition to the museums in Maharashtra, offers a mesmerizing exploration of India's maritime heritage. Located in the state's coastal region, the museum delves into the nation's deep-rooted connection with the sea. It showcases an impressive collection of maritime artifacts, historical documents, navigational instruments, and ship models, presenting a comprehensive insight into India's seafaring history. The exhibits narrate fascinating stories of ancient trade routes, maritime explorations, and naval prowess, unveiling the significant role the sea has played in shaping India's culture and economy. For history enthusiasts and maritime aficionados, the National Maritime Museum proves to be an enriching and enlightening experience.

The Raja Dinkar Kelkar Museum, a cherished cultural gem and a well-known historicalÂ museumÂ in Maharashtra, stands as a significant institution in Pune. Founded by the esteemed art collector and philanthropist, Raja Dinkar Kelkar, the museum boasts an impressive array of treasures. Among its highlights is a captivating replica of the Mastani Mahal, offering a glimpse into the opulent past. Additionally, the museum pays homage to the life and work ofÂ Mahatma GandhiÂ through a dedicated section, inspiring visitors with the ideals of non-violence and freedom. With its diverse and fascinating exhibits, the Raja Dinkar Kelkar Museum offers a memorable journey through art, history, and the enduring spirit of India.

The Shri Bhavani Museum, one of the well-known historical museum in Maharashtra, is a cultural treasure trove situated in the heart of the state. Named after its benefactor, Shri Bhavani, the museum is a testimony to his passion for preserving and showcasing the rich heritage of Maharashtra. Within its walls lie a diverse and captivating collection of artifacts, artworks, and historical memorabilia that offer a vivid glimpse into the region's past. From ancient artifacts to traditional crafts, the museum celebrates Maharashtra's artistic and historical legacy, making it a must-visit destination for anyone eager to delve into the vibrant tapestry of the state's cultural heritage.

The Tribal Museum, also known as the Tribal Research and Training Institute, stands as a unique and esteemed institution among museums in Maharashtra. Serving as a gateway to the fascinating world of Maharashtra's tribal communities, the museum houses a captivating collection of artifacts, objects, and materials that celebrate their rich culture and traditions. Beyond preservation, the institute plays a crucial role in working closely with tribal communities to document their customs, thus promoting their social, cultural, and economic development. This commendable effort fosters a deeper understanding and appreciation of the diverse tribal heritage, making the Tribal Museum a celebrated cultural hub in Maharashtra, drawing visitors from all walks of life.

The Veermata Museum, also known as Dr. Bhau Daji Lad Museum, is situated in Maharashtra and is a cherished cultural institution that pays tribute to the region's rich history and heritage. Formerly known as the Victoria and Albert Museum, it was renamed in honor of Queen Victoria's mother, Veermata Jijabai. The museum houses an extensive collection of artifacts, artworks, and historical treasures, spanning diverse periods and cultures. Visitors can explore a fascinating array of exhibits, including ancient sculptures, traditional crafts, and exquisite paintings. As one of the prominent museums in Maharashtra, the Veermata Museum stands as a testament to the state's vibrant past and offers a captivating journey through time for history enthusiasts and art lovers alike.

The Jehangir Art Gallery, a celebrated cultural museum in Maharashtra, holds a prominent place in Mumbai's vibrant art scene. Renowned for its focus on contemporary art, the gallery showcases captivating exhibitions featuring both established and emerging Indian artists. With its well-curated displays and diverse range of artistic expressions, the Jehangir Art Gallery attracts art enthusiasts, critics, and curious visitors alike. As a significant venue for promoting and appreciating Indian art, the gallery contributes to the cultural richness of Maharashtra and serves as a dynamic hub for artistic exploration and inspiration.

The Nehru Planetarium, a captivating destination among museums in Maharashtra, stands as a fascinating gateway to the wonders of the universe. Located in Mumbai, it is a tribute to India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, who envisioned popularizing scientific knowledge. The planetarium offers immersive and interactive astronomical experiences, including captivating shows on celestial phenomena and space exploration. It attracts visitors of all ages, from students to astronomy enthusiasts, who come to marvel at the mysteries of the cosmos. With its state-of-the-art facilities and educational programs, the Nehru Planetarium serves as a beacon of scientific curiosity, inspiring generations to gaze at the stars and explore the vastness of space.

It is then followed by a week long celebration when hundreds of people come to seek blessings. The beautiful British era architecture and the serene chapel will bring you the peace you seek.

The sum simmering down the stained glass windows, the limestone edifice, long aisle and the magnificent bells are a sight to see. The midnight mass here is always crowded and mass happens every day.

Francis De Sales Cathedral is indeed a popular church with an outstanding architecture. It is one of the churches in Nagpur known among Christians of catholic faith. And besides, there is also Sacraments of Holy Communion, Penance as well as Confirmation.

Home to iconic Mumbai hangouts like CafÃ© Mondegar and Leopold CafÃ©, Colaba Causeway is famed for its energetic and friendly vibe. Youâ€™ll find everything here â€“ from breezy apparels, colorful jewelry and antique clocks to brass knick-knacks, bags and trendy footwear. Usually filled with tourists, this street market also hosts upscale boutiques such as Bombay Electric and Bunglow 8 and offers an essential shopping experience in Mumbai. And when you get tired, head to eateries like Bagdadi, Bade Miyan or Light of Asia for a delicious meal. Whatâ€™s more? Colaba Causeway is in close proximity to majority of theÂ hotels in Mumbai.Â

Chaotic, colorful and oh-so-traditionalâ€¦ Crawford Market must be on your list ofÂ places for shopping in Mumbai. One of the cityâ€™s oldest markets, Crawford Market or Mahatma Jyotiba Phule Mandai as it is officially known now, is known for its wholesale shops selling fruits and veggies, home dÃ©cor accents, bags, makeup, toys and spices, and hold your breath â€¦ pets! It is equally famous for its grand structure, a curious mix of Norman and Flemish architecture, adorned with friezes designed by Lockwood Kipling, father of novelist Rudyard Kipling.

Are you in the market for some serious bling? Head to Zaveri Bazaar, just north of Crawford Market, for an eyeful of gold, silver, precious gems and opulent jewelry that could take your breath away! Shopping in Mumbai for wedding is never complete without stepping into the labyrinthine streets and by-lanes of Bhuleshwar, where Zaveri Bazaar is located. You could also buy high-end home dÃ©cor, dinnerware, furniture, toys and brassware here.

The most fashionable watches, mobile phones, laptops and every other kind of electronics call Heera Panna home. Even if youâ€™re on a street shopping trip to Mumbai, you canâ€™t miss this iconic market as it offers great deals. Just minutes away from another Mumbai icon, theÂ Haji Ali Dargah, Heera Panna has almost 140 shops selling electronics, imported cosmetics and chocolates as well as branded apparels and accessories. Pro tip: Shop for cheap knock-offs of branded items, perfumes as well as quality menâ€™s clothing here.

Rows upon rows of dried red chilies stacked in a conical mountain at the Mirchi Galli,Â giant mounds of dry snacks likeÂ farsanÂ and freshÂ kachorisÂ andÂ samosasâ€¦ this is what youâ€™ll see at the Lalbaug Market in Central Mumbai. You can easily getÂ 3 Star Hotels in Central MumbaiÂ under your budget. Also renowned for theÂ Lalbaug cha Raja,Â this market offers the authentic Mumbai experience you canâ€™t go home without. Go here for the spices, which you can pick at will and have them roasted and ground into fresh powder to take back with you!

Yards of saris in all kinds of fabric, material for dresses and readymade Indian wearâ€¦if these are a part of your shopping list, then head straight to the Hindmata Market in Dadar. Stand-alone tailoring shops punctuate this maze of streets, dotted with small family-owned shops which have been around for decades as well as glitzy new showrooms. Here youâ€™ll find every imaginable textile that is made in India and very often bolts of imported silk and synthetics. A must-visit for the budget-conscious, the Hindmata Market is one of the biggest and oldest wholesale fabric markets and a greatÂ place to visit in MumbaiÂ for wedding shopping.Â

Filled with shack-style shops selling affordable and on-trend clothes, jewelry, footwear and accessories, Linking Road should be your top destination for street shopping in Mumbai. By far one of the most popular street markets in the city, Linking Road has been featured in a Bollywood song starring Salman Khan and Raveena Tandon! Located in Bandra, one of the hippest neighborhoods in Mumbai, Linking Road street market is also home to some upscale branded showrooms and boutiques. If youâ€™re feeling a little adventurous, walk around the Mount Mary area close by to discover some little-known boutiques and designer ateliers.

Another great place to go street shopping in Mumbai is the Hill Road, where you would have to jostle with crowds and snarling traffic situation to get to one of its many shoe stores, high street shopping centers and malls. As always, be prepared to haggle with the street vendors and once youâ€™re done with your shopping, hop into Hearsch Bakery sitting inside a charming colonial-style bungalow and known for its giant burgers and home-style lemonade.

Further up from Bandra is the plush, crowded and coveted neighborhood of Lokhandwala in Andheri. This is where it gets reallyÂ filmyÂ because it would be tough to walk around without toppling over a celebrity! Theyâ€™re everywhere, and especially in the very chic Lokhandwala Market, a mishmash of branded stores, street vendors, eateries and residential buildings. If you are planning to shop in Mumbai, you must make a stop at this market for fashionable apparels and accessories, shops selling miles of fabric and tailors who can craft your dream outfit. Also, donâ€™t miss out on the first copies of international brands sold here!

Yadagirigutta is the most exceptional, lovely, and attractive hill with a pleasant climate throughout the year. Due to its proximity to the capital city, the flow of worshippers visiting the temple is extremely large. A minimum of 5000-8000 pilgrims often visit this temple every day to make promises and practise Saswata pujas, Saswata kalyanam, LakshaTulasi Pujas, Abhisekam, and many more. Overcrowding of visitors and worshippers is expected on weekends and other public holidays.

The Famous Telangana Temple, Balaji Temple is one of the most influential temples out there. Interestingly, the temple is famous for clearing the US and other western countries' Visa and thus, is also commonly known as Visa Balaji Temple. One of the oldest temples in the region it witnesses close to 100,000 devotees in a week. Visit the temple at any time of the year on any day. Fridays and Saturdays are the most crowded days of the week, so you would want to avoid that.
Timings: 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM

Birla Mandir in Hyderabad is an architectural beauty boasting of 2000 tonnes of white marble. The temple is located on a hilltop at the height of 280 feet which makes the structure look even more incredible. Constructed by the Birla group, the temple is the ideal place for meditating, given the fact that there are no bells here. There's a bit of climbing involved in reaching this holy site. After entering the place, you get a spectacular panoramic view of Hyderabad and Secunderabad which is worth the climb you take to reach the temple.
Timings: 6:00 AM to 12:00 PM,  2:00 PM to 9:00 PM

The temple is built in a Chola-Chalukya architectural style and is dedicated to not one but many Hindu Gods. Spotting the majestic Raja Gopuram from kilometres away is a common sight. You'll come across many more beautiful structures when you enter the temple. After performing the darshans, you should visit the Holy Garden to sit and unwind and breath in the religiosity in the air. Known to be an epitome of belief by the devotees, the temple witnesses thousands of visitors every week.
Timings: 8:00 AM to 1:00 PM, 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM

Located on the banks of the river Godavari in Basar village, the Gnana Saraswathi Temple has got rich history attached to it, going back to the time of Mahabharata. Dedicated to Goddess Saraswathi, the temple also made it to the list of best Sarawasthi temples of the country, which is probably why it is visited by thousands of devotees all round the year.
Timings: 4:00 AM to 9:00 PM

Surendrapuri is one of the few temples in India to have its mythological theme park. The place brims with culture, art, and amazing sculptures. Apart from the park being a significant tourist attraction, visitors can also pay a visit to the Nagakoti, a Shiva Linga standing tall at 101 feet and temples of Lord Hanuman and Lord Venkateswara. All deities in the temple are strategically placed, keeping in mind the Vedic knowledge used in building this one of a kind temple.
Timings: 6.30 AM to 1:00 PM, 3 PM to 8:00 PM

The Lakshmi Narasimha temple is Lord Narasimha's (embodiment of Lord Vishnu) abode. Due to its popularity, the temple is always bustling with devotees performing different types of darshans. The temple is located in a cave on a knoll in Yadadri Bhuvanagiri district. There are several chambers inside the temple, so it's worth taking a peaceful stroll on an evening and admiring the striking sculptures of deities spread all over the place.
Timings: 4:30 AM to 8:45 PM

Bhadrachalam is famous for its principal deity - Lord Rama. Vaikuntha Rama, to be more specific as this form of Rama is not present anywhere else in India but here. Legend says that the deity imparts knowledge to worshippers. The temple is also famous for the various festivals celebrated here, namely, Vasanthotsavam, Brahmotsavam, and Vaikuntha Ekadashi.
Timings: 6:00 AM to 8:30 PM

The Thousand Pillars Temple is one of the best architecture structures out there. The temple is also added to the tentative UNESCO top heritage sites list. Mainly dedicated to three deities, Lord Vishnu, Surya, and Shiva, the temple was built in the 12th century. Recently, the temple was on the verge of collapsing but was saved by the government. A famous tourist destination, it is now being renovated with each of the pillars being marked and numbered for the process of elevation.
Timings: 6:00 AM to 8:00 PM

The Ramappa Temple lies tucked in the beautiful valley of Palampet village, roughly 157 km away from Hyderabad. Interestingly, the temple is named after its creator (sculpture) and not the deity, which is quite unusual in India. Lord Ramalingeswara, yet another form of Lord Shiva is worshipped here by thousands of devotees who visit the temple every year. As a tourist, there's a lot to look at. The deity stands tall at a tremendous star-shaped platform, and the pillars of the temple also have beautiful carvings.
Timings: 4:00 AM to 8:00 PM

Sangameshwar temple is an ancient holy shrine dedicated to Lord Shiva. Lord Shiva in the form of Shiva Lingam is the chief presiding deity in the temple. Sangameshwar Temple is the most prominent one amongst 15 other temples dedicated to Lord Shiva in the area. It is said to be built 200 years ago, a few years after the British colonised India.
Timings: 5:00 AM to 8:00 PM

Ujjaini Mahankali Temple is a 191 years old temple located in Secunderabad, Telangana. Thousands of devotees visit this place to seek blessings of Goddess Mahankali. During July and August, the temple is illuminated with electric lights and decorated with garlands, buntings and festoons for the festival of Mahankali Ammari Jathra. It is an annual event that glorifies peace, harmony and security of the people endowed by Goddess Mahankaliâ€™s blessings. There are abhisheks, poojas and serving of prasadam to the Goddess every day by hundreds of people.

Located in Banjara Hills, Hyderabad, Jagannath Temple is a modern Hindu temple built by the Odia community dedicated to Hindu God Jagannath- God of the Universe.
Constructed in red sandstone, the Jagannath temple follows the ancient shikhara style pattern. Besides the main deity, the temple has smaller shrines dedicated to Lakshmi, Shiva, Ganesha, Hanuman and Navagraha.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Timings : Monday - Sunday: 6:00 AM - 11:00 AM and 5:00 PM - 9:00 PM

A welcome arch with idols of Lord Shiva and Parvati with Lord Ganesh and Lord Subrahmanya on either side greets the devotees. The temple tower is beautifully decorated with figurines of Lord Shiva and his Parivar (family). On the back side of the tower one can see the figurines of Sri Kalahasthiswara and that of Kannappa worshipping Shiva. A beautiful Nandi statue is seen in the hall facing the inner sanctum.

Known to be an ideal trekking path for adventure lovers, it is this route through which the travelers have to climb more than 500 steps to reach the top of the Medak Fort. Spread across an area of about 100 acres, the fort was built in the 12th century during the reign of the Kakatiya ruler, Prataparudra. It is definitely one of the challenging trekking places near Hyderabad and a must-visit for experts in trekking.
Altitude: 442 m

Ananthagiri is also popular for trekking camps in Hyderabad. There are two trekking trails in the forests, one that begins from the Anantha Padmanabha Swamy Temple, and another one that starts 0.5 kms from the temple towards Kerelli. The small reservoir, the lush green jungle, the trail covered by thick vegetation, and the beautiful freshwater streams are a treat for the trekkers.
Altitude: 700 m

A popular Hyderabad getaway for a short trip and an important historical site, the Bhongir Fort is located at a distance of 1.3 kms from the Bhuvanagiri Railway Station. The hill upon which the fort is perched, is about 500 ft. high, and is spread across an area of 40 acres that makes it an ideal for trekking in Hyderabad. It usually takes about one hour to reach atop the hill and make sure you carry enough water.

Koilkonda Fort and Koilsagar Dam are considered to be the most adventurous places in Hyderabad. To reach the top of Koilkonda Fort one needs to hike across a deep gorge on the west, and a series of streams on the east before reaching a plight of steps that leads to the fort. The Koilsagar Dam is about 10 kms from the Koilkonda Fort, and the trekking trails stretch across River Peddavagu.

Built on a rocky hill by King Gona Ganapa Reddy, the Ghanpur Fort dates back to the time of 13th century. There are several temples inside the fort like Veerabhadra Temple, Narasimha Temple, and Chowdeshwari Temple along with which, trekkers can also explore the several caves on the hilltop.

Wonderla Amusement Park in Hyderabad has India's first reverse roller coaster ride. It has a one-time payment facility, and you can enjoy any ride as many times as you want to. What makes people love Wonderla, even more, is the fact that it has rides for all age groups, making it easy for people to decide, where to have a family picnic. This fun-filled family destination has 43 rides and is open on all seven days from 11:00 AM to 6:00 PM with differences in the ticket price per day. There are 25 land-based rides and 18 water-based rides.

Escape Water and Adventure Park in Hyderabad is open throughout the week from 11:00 AM - 6:00 PM. It offers one of the most entertaining facilities with unique rides and activities for kids. The theme park is divided into two zones, the water zone and the adventure zone, with a variety of rides. It also offers lockers to pack your stuff in and a lavish food court.

Leonia Splash is located inside the Leonia Resort Hyderabad and offers exclusive packages where you could indulge in many water sports and activities. The packages also include a DJ rain dance. With the most courteous staff at work, they also ensure the safety of the visitors. The timings are from 10:00 AM -11:00 PM, with quite a beautiful nightlife.

Ocean Park is one of the first three theme parks in Hyderabad. It has two sections, one for water sports and one for amusement games. This amusement park has water rides, a kiddies pool, a wave pool, water slides and dry slides. The price of most of the rides is included in the entry fee while some rides are paid. One has to wear a swimming costume only which one can either rent or get their own. The park timings are from 11:00 AM-7:30 PM with a pretty economical ticket rate. There are special rates for college and school students.

Mount Opera is the biggest Multi Theme Park in Hyderabad. Placed on the hilltop, this park provides many water sports as well as dry rides like Skating Rink, Toy Train, Merry-Go-Round, Merry Cups, Slam Bob, Columbus, Sliding Ring, Skating Rink, Striking Cars, Tele-Combat, Ferris wheel, Go-Karting, etc. There are slides for adults too, with wave pools and a separate pool for families and kids. Facilities like rain dance and boating are also provided along with some indoor games like carom, billiards, table tennis and a lot more.

Being one of the popular water parks in Hyderabad, Jalavihar is an entertainment family park. The setting of the park is in two zones, the party zone and the entertainment zone. The party zone further is divided into three zones, according to the gatherings and accommodation. The entertainment zone houses a wave pool, dry rides, rain dance, gaming zone, and food court. There is a dress code that needs to be followed, and Jalavihar also provides costumes for rent.

The Dream Valley Water Park is located in the Dream Valley resort. With amazing water slides, splash pads, spray grounds and a large swimming pool, the water park is one of the biggest fun zones in South India. You can buy a day visit package for the resort which includes access to the water park, food, drinks, a rain dance and a swimming pool. You can also book an overnight stay at their ethnic cottages and farmhouses.

The main attraction of this museum is the planetarium, science center, and the art gallery. One of the most interesting things is the dinosaurian.
This museum is constructed as the second phase of the science gallery. This dinosarioum consists of the 160 million-year-old carcass of Kotasaurus Yamanpalliensis which was found in the excavation at the district of Adilabad. This museum also has different tiny fossils of marine shells and fossilized trunks of old trees.

This museum is the amalgamation of medieval and modern royal art. It is located at Darushifa which resides at the southern bank of the Musi River. This museum comes under the national museum of India due to its rich collections. It has collections of carvings, textiles, manuscripts, artifacts, and carpets from different countries such as China, Burma, Egypt, North America, Japan, and Nepal.

This museum displays a wide range of antiquities and art collectibles. These are reconciled from the areas of Yeleswaram and Srisailam Reservoirs of Krishna valley. This museum also contains the collectibles excavated from all over the state.
This heritage museum consists of prehistoric and other artifacts that are excavated from the different archaeological projects. This also consists of Paleolithic tools which are from the prehistoric times. The major attraction of this museum is the showcasing of burial practices about the megalithic times.

This is one of a kind museum that is truly a treat for historians. This museum is widely popular among the museum lovers due to its infrastructure. The rulers of this dynasty are great builders and lovers of learning. They constructed the different structures related to religions, arsenal, and bridges.
The architectural styles are a combination of local granite and traditional materials which makes the infrastructure quite rich in terms of artistic work. It also showcases weapons, armor and other utensils from the Qutb Shahi period. The availability of different amenities such as clean drinking water, restrooms make this museum easily accessible.

Golconda still boasts of mounted cannons, four drawbridges, eight gateways, and majestic halls, magazines, stables etc. The outermost enclosure is called Fateh Darwaza meaning Victory gate, after Aurangzebâ€™s army marched successfully through this gate. At Fateh Darwaza one can witness fantastic acoustical effects, which is one among the many famous engineering marvels at Golconda.

Hyderabad's prized possession stands tall at its centre, The Charminar. This historical wonder erected by Sultan Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah in 1591 serves as an emblematic piece celebrating the city's tradition and opulence. Its grandeur attracts throngs of tourists year after year.

The location of Charminar holds historical significance as well. It was built at the intersection of the bustling markets of Hyderabad, serving as a central point for trade and commerce during the Qutb Shahi dynasty. The monument derives its name from its four towering minarets, which are said to represent the four pillars of Islam. You will have a wonderful time exploring this wonder.

This lake was constructed by tapping a small part of the tributary of River Krishna. In the later years, a sanctuary was built around the area.
It is very beautiful to watch the sight of deer, panthers, tigers, leopards roaming around freely in the area. The lush green locales set against the backdrop of a bluish lake provides enhancement to the view. People of all age groups would love to visit this park. Many buses ply from Warangal to this lake.
Location: Warangal, Telangana

Eturnagaram Wildlife Sanctuary is one of the oldest sanctuaries in South India. The wildlife sanctuary was developed by the Nizam of Hyderabad. The sanctuary shares borders with three states in the country namely Chhattisgarh, Telangana and Maharashtra.
There is a water source called Dayyam Vagu that divides the wildlife sanctuary into exactly two areas. A small river joins along with the River Godavari that makes this park a delight to watch during the monsoon season. This sanctuary looks more or less like a private national park for one can take oneâ€™s private jeep inside the premises of the sanctuary.
Location: Warangal, Telangana

A wildlife sanctuary has been built around the dam to make this area into a tourist attraction. This place was earlier used as hunting grounds for the Nizams. Name any animals, birds, plants, one can find it in this park. There is a huge watchtower inside the premises from which one can get a panoramic view of the entire location.
There are about nine islands within the park, which is home to a lot of different species of fishes, turtles and other marine life. One can have a great time playing in the waters and also gorging on some fresh fish caught in the waters of the dam.
Location: Medak and Nizamabad, Telangana State

There is a forest called Dandakaranya which is located near the sanctuary. The river cuts this sanctuary into two halves and later joins with River Godavari.
Many islands are located within the premises of the sanctuary. There are many beautiful locations like the glasshouse and an eco-park within the premises of the sanctuary. The vegetation of the sanctuary is a mix of lush green and deciduous. One can spend an entire day at the sanctuary without getting bored as it has got a lot to offer.
Location: Telangana

This National Park is located near Chilkur Lake. It is a true treasure for the deep forest region, which is found with all the varieties of birds and animals which roam around freely in the region.
There is a watchtower inside the park from where the animals can be watched very closely. Snake shows are also conducted during certain days of the week. There is a library inside the park, which educates the visitors about the habitat of animals that dot the region.
Location: Moinabad, Ranga Reddy District, Chilkur

This National Park was named after the late Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh, Kasu Brahmananda Reddy. The park was opened in the year 1994 to preserve and protect the rich variety of flora and fauna which are found in the region.
The park was renovated in the year 2002 to provide a wide pathway for the visitors to take a stroll around the park. The walkway is dotted by many beautiful birds like a peacock, which provides a lot of grace to the view while touring around the park. The park is visited by many prominent film personalities for a morning walk.
Location: Jubilee Hills, Hyderabad

Nehru Zoological Park located in the heart of the city is one of the largest national parks in the country. The park is also visited by the locals as well as tourists. It is very well maintained and one can find all kinds of animals, birds and other varieties of flora and fauna. There is a National History Museum within the premises of the park. The children can enjoy touring the park by hopping on the train ride. For those who cannot walk around the large area of the park, one can prefer the safari ride.
Location: Bahadurpura, Hyderabad

The Kawal Tiger Reserve is one of the most significant locations in India. It is a continuous stretch of the national park that connects Indravati National Park, which is to the east of the Kawal Tiger Reserve and Tadoba Tiger Reserve which is located north to Kawal. This enables free movement of tigers and other large variety of wildlife.
This tiger reserve is the home to some of the exotic species of tigers in the world. Not only tigers, but there are also many varieties of leopards, flying squirrels, Indian civets, porcupines, leopard, jackal that are found here. One can also stay in the nearby resorts in the forest region to get a taste of wilderness.
Location: Jannaram, Telangana

Spread over 92 acres on land on the banks of Hussain Sagar Lake, Sanjeevaiah Park is dedicated to the former President of India Dr Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy.Replete with lush green trees, flowering shrubs, fountains and glossy grass lawns, the park is the perfect place to rewind and rejuvenate from the daily routine life.                                                                                                      Timings : Monday - Sunday: 9:00 AM - 6:00 PM

Lumbini Park is a gorgeous urban park named after Lumbini of Nepal. Located alongside Hussain Sagar, the park has an artificial water tank.A huge statue of Lord Buddha is installed in the tank which can be reached through paddle boats. The Lumbini Park also holds musical fountain shows and is an important tourist spot in the city.                                                                              Timings : Monday - Sunday: 9:00 AM to 9:00 PM

Located adjacent to the Hussain Sagar Lake in Hyderabad, NTR Gardens is a tiny but gorgeous park dotted with brightly coloured plants and tall trees.Boasting of well-groomed landscaping, ornate lamp posts and brilliant water fountains, the NTR Gardens park also has a souvenir shop, toy train, freefall, restaurants and variety of fun activities for both kids and adults. Timings : Monday - Saturday: 2:30 PM - 8:30 PM;
Sundays: 12:30 PM - 8:30 PM

Named after the former Prime Minister Smt. Indira Gandhi park houses tall towering trees and plenty of shrubs and flowering place.Spread over an area of 76 acres, Indira Park is believed to have been built in the year 1975. The park is a popular tourist spot in the city.                                                                                                                                                                                                           Timings : Monday - Sunday: 5:00 AM - 8:00 PM

The Waterfalls flow through a rock which appears to be an impression of the legendary hero Bheema's footprint, hence, the name Bheemuni Paadam. As the water cascades through the smooth rocks and falls at a height of 70 feet at the bottom, the pretty sight is the real reward of the journey to this place.

Gayatri Waterfalls which is locally known as Gadidha Gundam or Mukti Gundam is a hidden gem. Located in a faraway spot amidst the dense forest near Tarnam Khurd, this place is a heavenly retreat if someone needs some time off from the urban chaos. These falls cascade down from a height of approximately 100 ft and render a magical charm to the valley below. Tourists can swim in the pool below and have a gala time clicking pictures here. It is ideal to pack a snack and water while visiting this place as there are no eateries in the area.
Best Time to Visit: August- October

the thunder of falling waters of the Pochera Falls has the potential to create an impressive scenic spot. A popular waterfall near Hyderabad, it goes through a series of steps to finally create a pool at the height of about 40 feet. The area around the park is well-maintained by the State Tourism Department. During the peak monsoon seasons, it is advisable not to get into the pool as the water flow is intense.
Best Time to Visit: September-October

Kanakai Waterfalls in the Girnur village in Telangana is an impassable 30 feet high cascade of water stream descending from a cliff into a large pool at the bottom of the falls. The roaring of water as it strikes down and envelops everything into the roaring white blanket is truly a sight to behold. The waterfalls are a great location to trek, you can also witness a great panoramic view of the whole waterfall and its neighbouring landscapes from the top of the cliff. The drive to the waterfalls is reason enough for you to make a trip up to Kanakai with some of the most picturesque views that you could witness in the countryside.
Best Time to Visit: Around September - October

A picturesque waterfall in the district of Khammam, the Bogatha waterfall provides an opportunity for the visitor to witness the spectacle of waters cascading into the faces of the cliff, carving out a topography unlike any, thus the epithet, 'Niagara Of Telangana'. As a motorable road is not available, visitors need to trek for some distance thus enabling nature enthusiasts to indulge in the serenity of the greenery around.
Best Time to Visit: June to November

Falling at the height of 200 feet, Kuntala Falls are located in the middle of the Sahyadri mountain range. A popular tourist destination in Telangana, Kadam River is the source of these Falls. The ideal time to visit this place is during the monsoon season when the Kuntala Falls has an excellent water flow, and the surroundings are covered in a lush green carpet. One might find small shops selling packaged drinking water and biscuits here.
Best Time to Visit: Monsoon (September-October)

TOT is one of the best night clubs in the town which offers a London like clubbing experience. Other than the lip-smacking finger food, and different cuisines from all over the world, there are also amazing cocktails for you to try. However, the highlight of the club is the several international artists that frequently come here to perform. Some of the popular ones include Justin Mylo, Myris and Shiv etc. With amazing decor and groundbreaking music, the club gives the other bars a run for their money.Timings: 8 PM - 12:30 AM

Prism is Indiaâ€™s first nightclub that draws from an international standard lighting system. Although the USP of the club is itâ€™s the lighting system, but the bombastic sound, amazing food and uplifting music are equally good. Boasting of an exuberant capacity, the nightclub has groovy sounds and a magnificent floor where you can shake a leg or two. And while you are at it, do not forget to try there out of the world concoctions, mocktails and cocktails.
Timings: 5 PM - 12 AM

Carpe Diem is currently one of the most popular places to go clubbing and partying in Hyderabad right now. Boasting of the largest island bar in town, the bar also has very quirky and dazzling lights and flaunts a cosy dark ambience. Frequented mainly by the youth of the city, Carpe Diem is also considered one of the best places to go party with your bae. They also have an elevated VIP section which has bottle service and table booking in advance. Besides, the decor is luxurious with suede and leather seating. Last but not the least, they have delicious finger-licking food to satiate your appetite.Timings: 8 PM - 12 AM

By the Bay is one of the latest additions to the glittery hangout places of Hyderabad. With a seating capacity of over 170 people, the cafe cum bar has outdoor seating where you can enjoy your food and drinks overlooking the beautiful views of the lake. The restaurant is spread over two floors and the unique thing about the bar is that the price of the drinks keeps going up and down, like in an actual stock exchange.
Timings: 12 PM - 12:45 AM

While Hyderabad boasts of great pub culture, there are also a good many things which non-party crowd can indulge in. If you are a-walk-by-the-lake kind of a person then Tank Bund area is the ideal spot for you. The lighted Buddha Statue in the centre of the Hussain Sagar lake is a mesmerizing sight. The other spots which are also heart-winners at night are Birla Mandir, NTR Gardens and Lumbini Park.

Laad Bazar stretches about a Kilometer and is packed with bangles and other stuff. It is located in the west of Charminar. It is a bit crowded though due to its popularity, to counter it the use of cars and rickshaws has been barred. One has to walk through the lane or use a motorcycle to explore. To widen the image, all these products are in the same place in even the next shop. There are 350 of it! If you take it from us go and buy some stuff, you will not regret it. Brush up your bargaining or visit with someone who knows the place, heavy bargaining is the soul of the market.

the area of Char Minar stands out with its rustic charm. It is renowned for the Barsa Pearl embellished with gold and silver that's well known in the world. This is one of the best markets in Hyderabad.

Shilparamam gives its visitors a village shopping experience in Hyderabad. The place has a setting of 15 huts made in a rural way so that it supports the theme of the products. The place serves as an exhibition and a market for Handicrafts, genuine natural fabrics and goods. Shilparamam village also has a museum and recreational areas too.

The market is famous for its century-old business that has been passed on through generations. You wouldn't need to search for it, the fragrances of the perfumes called Ittar will pull you towards the destination.
Then Sunday Book Bazaar is your spot. Apart from buying a book, the Sunday book bazaar lets you sell your used books and part your knowledge.
